section_path: Advances in technology and its application
section_body:
Main article: [Technology during World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technology_during_World_War_II "Technology during World War II")

[![Image 51](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Bundesarchiv_Bild_146-1978-Anh.026-01%2C_Peenem%C3%BCnde%2C_V2_beim_Start.jpg/250px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_146-1978-Anh.026-01%2C_Peenem%C3%BCnde%2C_V2_beim_Start.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_146-1978-Anh.026-01,_Peenem%C3%BCnde,_V2_beim_Start.jpg)

A [V-2 rocket](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V-2_rocket "V-2 rocket") launched from a fixed site in [Peenemünde](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peenem%C3%BCnde "Peenemünde"), 21 June 1943

Aircraft were used for [reconnaissance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reconnaissance_aircraft "Reconnaissance aircraft"), as [fighters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fighter_aircraft "Fighter aircraft"), [bombers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bomber "Bomber"), and [ground-support](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Close_air_support "Close air support"), and each role developed considerably. Innovations included [airlift](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airlift "Airlift") (the capability to quickly move limited high-priority supplies, equipment, and personnel);[[433]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-EncWWII_76-437) and [strategic bombing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_bombing "Strategic bombing") (the bombing of enemy industrial and population centres to destroy the enemy's ability to wage war).[[434]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-438)[Anti-aircraft weaponry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-aircraft_warfare "Anti-aircraft warfare") also advanced, including defences such as [radar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radar "Radar") and surface-to-air artillery, in particular the introduction of the [proximity fuze](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proximity_fuze "Proximity fuze"). The use of the [jet aircraft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jet_aircraft "Jet aircraft") was pioneered and led to jets becoming standard in air forces worldwide.[[435]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-439)

Advances were made in nearly every aspect of [naval warfare](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naval_warfare "Naval warfare"), most notably with [aircraft carriers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aircraft_carrier "Aircraft carrier") and [submarines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Submarine "Submarine"). Although [aeronautical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aeronautics "Aeronautics") warfare had relatively little success at the start of the war, [actions at Taranto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Taranto "Battle of Taranto"), [Pearl Harbor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor "Attack on Pearl Harbor"), and the [Coral Sea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Coral_Sea "Battle of the Coral Sea") established the carrier as the dominant capital ship (in place of the battleship).[[436]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-EncWWII_163-440)[[437]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-441)[[438]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-442) In the Atlantic, [escort carriers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escort_carrier "Escort carrier") became a vital part of Allied convoys, increasing the effective protection radius and helping to close the [Mid-Atlantic gap](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid-Atlantic_gap "Mid-Atlantic gap").[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-443) Carriers were also more economical than [battleships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battleship "Battleship") due to the relatively low cost of aircraft[[440]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-444) and because they are not required to be as heavily armoured.[[441]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-445) Submarines, which had proved to be an effective weapon during the [First World War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"),[[442]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-Bur&Ryd_1995_15-446) were expected by all combatants to be important in the second. The British focused development on [anti-submarine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-submarine_warfare "Anti-submarine warfare")[weaponry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-submarine_weapon "Anti-submarine weapon") and tactics, such as [sonar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonar "Sonar") and convoys, while Germany focused on improving its offensive capability, with designs such as the [Type VII submarine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_VII_submarine "Type VII submarine") and [wolfpack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolfpack_(naval_tactic) "Wolfpack (naval tactic)") tactics.[[443]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-Bur&Ryd_1995_16-447) Gradually, improving Allied technologies such as the [Leigh Light](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leigh_Light "Leigh Light"), [Hedgehog](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hedgehog_(weapon) "Hedgehog (weapon)"), [Squid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squid_(weapon) "Squid (weapon)"), and [homing torpedoes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_24_mine "Mark 24 mine") proved effective against German submarines.[[444]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-448)

[![Image 52](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Trinity_device_readied.jpg/250px-Trinity_device_readied.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Trinity_device_readied.jpg)

Nuclear _Gadget_ being raised to the top of the detonation "shot tower", at [Alamogordo Bombing Range](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alamogordo_Bombing_and_Gunnery_Range "Alamogordo Bombing and Gunnery Range"); [Trinity nuclear test](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trinity_(nuclear_test) "Trinity (nuclear test)"), [New Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico"), July 1945

[Land warfare](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_warfare "Land warfare") changed from the static frontlines of [trench warfare](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trench_warfare "Trench warfare") of World War I, which had relied on improved [artillery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artillery "Artillery") that outmatched the speed of both [infantry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infantry "Infantry") and [cavalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cavalry "Cavalry"), to increased mobility and [combined arms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combined_arms "Combined arms"). The [tank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tank "Tank"), which had been used predominantly for infantry support in the First World War, had evolved into the primary weapon.[[445]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-EncWWII_125-449) In the late 1930s, tank design was considerably more advanced than it had been during World War I,[[446]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-450) and [advances continued throughout the war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tanks_in_World_War_II "Tanks in World War II") with increases in speed, armour and firepower.[[447]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-451)[[448]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-452) At the start of the war, most commanders thought enemy tanks should be met by tanks with superior specifications.[[449]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-EncWWII_108-453) This idea was challenged by the poor performance of the relatively light early tank guns against armour, and German doctrine of avoiding tank-versus-tank combat. This, along with Germany's use of combined arms, were among the key elements of their highly successful blitzkrieg tactics across Poland and France.[[445]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-EncWWII_125-449) Many means of [destroying tanks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-tank_warfare "Anti-tank warfare"), including [indirect artillery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indirect_fire "Indirect fire"), [anti-tank guns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-tank_gun "Anti-tank gun") (both towed and [self-propelled](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-propelled_artillery "Self-propelled artillery")), [mines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-tank_mine "Anti-tank mine"), short-ranged infantry antitank weapons, and other tanks were used.[[449]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-EncWWII_108-453) Even with large-scale mechanisation, infantry remained the backbone of all forces,[[450]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-EncWWII_734-454) and throughout the war, most infantry were equipped similarly to World War I.[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-Comp_221-455) The portable machine gun spread, a notable example being the German [MG 34](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MG_34 "MG 34"), and various [submachine guns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Submachine_gun "Submachine gun") which were suited to [close combat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Close_combat "Close combat") in urban and jungle settings.[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-Comp_221-455) The [assault rifle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assault_rifle "Assault rifle"), a late war development incorporating many features of the rifle and submachine gun, became the standard post-war infantry weapon for most armed forces.[[452]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-456)

Most major belligerents attempted to solve the problems of complexity and security involved in using large [codebooks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Codebook "Codebook") for [cryptography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography "Cryptography") by designing [ciphering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cipher "Cipher") machines, the most well-known being the German [Enigma machine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enigma_machine "Enigma machine").[[453]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-457) Development of [SIGINT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SIGINT "SIGINT") (_sig_ nals _int_ elligence) and [cryptanalysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptanalysis "Cryptanalysis") enabled the countering process of decryption. Notable examples were the Allied decryption of [Japanese naval codes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_naval_codes "Japanese naval codes")[[454]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-Schoenherr-458) and British [Ultra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultra_(cryptography) "Ultra (cryptography)"), a [pioneering method](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bombe#The_British_Bombe "Bombe") for decoding Enigma that benefited from information given to the United Kingdom by the [Polish Cipher Bureau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cipher_Bureau_(Poland)#Gift_to_allies "Cipher Bureau (Poland)"), which had been decoding early versions of Enigma before the war.[[455]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-459) Another component of [military intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_intelligence "Military intelligence") was [deception](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deception "Deception"), which the Allies used to great effect in operations such as [Mincemeat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Mincemeat "Operation Mincemeat") and [Bodyguard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Bodyguard "Operation Bodyguard").[[454]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-Schoenherr-458)[[456]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-460)

Other technological and engineering feats achieved during, or as a result of, the war include the world's first programmable computers ([Z3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z3_(computer) "Z3 (computer)"), [Colossus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colossus_computer "Colossus computer"), and [ENIAC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ENIAC "ENIAC")), [guided missiles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V-1_flying_bomb "V-1 flying bomb") and [modern rockets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V-2_rocket "V-2 rocket"), the [Manhattan Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan_Project "Manhattan Project")'s development of [nuclear weapons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_weapon "Nuclear weapon"), [operations research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operations_research "Operations research"), the development of [artificial harbours](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mulberry_harbour "Mulberry harbour"), and [oil pipelines under the English Channel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Pluto "Operation Pluto").[[457]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-461)[[458]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-462) Although [penicillin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penicillin "Penicillin") was discovered before the war, the [development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_penicillin "History of penicillin")] of industrial production technology as well as the mass production and use began during the war.[[459]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-463)

triples.statement: Innovations in aircraft use included airlift, for moving high-priority supplies and personnel, and strategic bombing, which targeted enemy industrial and population centers.

triples.sentence: The use of the [jet aircraft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jet_aircraft "Jet aircraft") was pioneered and led to jets becoming standard in air forces worldwide.[[435]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-439)
triples.statement: The pioneering use of jet aircraft during the war led to them becoming standard in global air forces.

triples.sentence: Although [aeronautical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aeronautics "Aeronautics") warfare had relatively little success at the start of the war, [actions at Taranto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Taranto "Battle of Taranto"), [Pearl Harbor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor "Attack on Pearl Harbor"), and the [Coral Sea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Coral_Sea "Battle of the Coral Sea") established the carrier as the dominant capital ship (in place of the battleship).[[436]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-EncWWII_163-440)[[437]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-441)[[438]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-442)
triples.statement: Despite early limited success, actions at Taranto, Pearl Harbor, and the Coral Sea established the aircraft carrier as the dominant capital ship, replacing the battleship.

triples.sentence: In the Atlantic, [escort carriers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escort_carrier "Escort carrier") became a vital part of Allied convoys, increasing the effective protection radius and helping to close the [Mid-Atlantic gap](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid-Atlantic_gap "Mid-Atlantic gap").[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-443)
triples.statement: Escort carriers in the Atlantic were vital for Allied convoys, extending their protection radius and helping to close the Mid-Atlantic gap.

triples.sentence: Carriers were also more economical than [battleships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battleship "Battleship") due to the relatively low cost of aircraft[[440]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-444) and because they are not required to be as heavily armoured.[[441]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-445)
triples.statement: Aircraft carriers were more economical than battleships because of the lower cost of aircraft and less need for heavy armor.

triples.sentence: Submarines, which had proved to be an effective weapon during the [First World War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"),[[442]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-Bur&Ryd_1995_15-446) were expected by all combatants to be important in the second.
triples.statement: Having proven effective in World War I, submarines were expected by all combatants to be important in World War II.

triples.sentence: The British focused development on [anti-submarine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-submarine_warfare "Anti-submarine warfare")[weaponry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-submarine_weapon "Anti-submarine weapon") and tactics, such as [sonar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonar "Sonar") and convoys, while Germany focused on improving its offensive capability, with designs such as the [Type VII submarine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_VII_submarine "Type VII submarine") and [wolfpack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolfpack_(naval_tactic) "Wolfpack (naval tactic)") tactics.[[443]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-Bur&Ryd_1995_16-447)
triples.statement: The British focused on developing anti-submarine weaponry and tactics like sonar and convoys, whereas Germany concentrated on improving offensive capabilities with designs like the Type VII submarine and wolfpack tactics.

triples.sentence: The [tank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tank "Tank"), which had been used predominantly for infantry support in the First World War, had evolved into the primary weapon.[[445]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-EncWWII_125-449)
triples.statement: The tank, primarily an infantry support weapon in World War I, evolved to become the primary weapon in World War II.

triples.sentence: In the late 1930s, tank design was considerably more advanced than it had been during World War I,[[446]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-450) and [advances continued throughout the war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tanks_in_World_War_II "Tanks in World War II") with increases in speed, armour and firepower.[[447]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-451)[[448]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-452)
triples.statement: By the late 1930s, tank design was much more advanced than in World War I, and improvements in speed, armor, and firepower continued throughout the war.

triples.sentence: At the start of the war, most commanders thought enemy tanks should be met by tanks with superior specifications.[[449]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-EncWWII_108-453)
triples.statement: At the beginning of the war, most commanders believed that enemy tanks should be countered by tanks with superior specifications.

triples.sentence: This, along with Germany's use of combined arms, were among the key elements of their highly successful blitzkrieg tactics across Poland and France.[[445]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-EncWWII_125-449)
triples.statement: Germany's doctrine of avoiding tank-versus-tank combat, combined with their use of combined arms, were key elements of their successful blitzkrieg tactics in Poland and France.

triples.sentence: Many means of [destroying tanks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-tank_warfare "Anti-tank warfare"), including [indirect artillery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indirect_fire "Indirect fire"), [anti-tank guns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-tank_gun "Anti-tank gun") (both towed and [self-propelled](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-propelled_artillery "Self-propelled artillery")), [mines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-tank_mine "Anti-tank mine"), short-ranged infantry antitank weapons, and other tanks were used.[[449]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-EncWWII_108-453)
triples.statement: A variety of methods were used to destroy tanks, including indirect artillery, anti-tank guns, mines, short-range infantry weapons, and other tanks.

triples.sentence: Even with large-scale mechanisation, infantry remained the backbone of all forces,[[450]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-EncWWII_734-454) and throughout the war, most infantry were equipped similarly to World War I.[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-Comp_221-455)
triples.statement: Despite large-scale mechanization, infantry remained the core of all forces, and for most of the war, their equipment was similar to that of World War I.

triples.sentence: The portable machine gun spread, a notable example being the German [MG 34](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MG_34 "MG 34"), and various [submachine guns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Submachine_gun "Submachine gun") which were suited to [close combat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Close_combat "Close combat") in urban and jungle settings.[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-Comp_221-455)
triples.statement: The use of portable machine guns, like the German MG 34, and various submachine guns suited for close combat in urban and jungle environments became widespread.

triples.sentence: Most major belligerents attempted to solve the problems of complexity and security involved in using large [codebooks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Codebook "Codebook") for [cryptography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography "Cryptography") by designing [ciphering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cipher "Cipher") machines, the most well-known being the German [Enigma machine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enigma_machine "Enigma machine").[[453]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-457)
triples.statement: To address the complexity and security issues of large codebooks, most major belligerents designed ciphering machines, with the German Enigma machine being the most famous.

triples.sentence: Notable examples were the Allied decryption of [Japanese naval codes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_naval_codes "Japanese naval codes")[[454]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-Schoenherr-458) and British [Ultra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultra_(cryptography) "Ultra (cryptography)"), a [pioneering method](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bombe#The_British_Bombe "Bombe") for decoding Enigma that benefited from information given to the United Kingdom by the [Polish Cipher Bureau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cipher_Bureau_(Poland)#Gift_to_allies "Cipher Bureau (Poland)"), which had been decoding early versions of Enigma before the war.[[455]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-459)
triples.statement: Notable examples of decryption include the Allied breaking of Japanese naval codes and the British Ultra program, which decoded Enigma with early assistance from the Polish Cipher Bureau.

triples.sentence: Another component of [military intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_intelligence "Military intelligence") was [deception](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deception "Deception"), which the Allies used to great effect in operations such as [Mincemeat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Mincemeat "Operation Mincemeat") and [Bodyguard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Bodyguard "Operation Bodyguard").[[454]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-Schoenherr-458)[[456]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II#cite_note-460)
triples.statement: Deception was another key component of military intelligence, used effectively by the Allies in operations like Mincemeat and Bodyguard.
